case_name: Mohd. Subrati alias Mohd. Karim v. District Magistrate, Burdwan

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 307 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 307 of 1972. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner is Mohd. Subrati alias Mohd. Karim detained in Burdwan Jail.

anchor.surface_text: pursuant to the impugned order of detention dated February 9, 1972 made by the District Magistrate, Burdwan in exercise of the powers companyferred on him by sub-s.  1  read

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner at time of arrest on February 11, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The ground of detention were duly served on him at the time of his arrest on February 11, 1972. Those grounds are That on 6-1-72 at about 03.30 has.

facts.text: On January 6, 1972 at about 03.30 hrs, petitioner along with associates Teka Bahadur son of Harak Bir Bahadur of Hutton Road and Ganesh Das son of Chote Das of Gour Mondal Road, both P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan, committed theft of electric copper wire about 1500 ft at Hatgarui near Sen-Releigh Water Pump, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan, disrupting water and electric supply for about 8 hours.

anchor.surface_text: That on 6-1-72 at about 03.30 has. you along with your associates including  1  teka Bahadur son of Shri Harak Bir Bahadur of Hutton Road, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan,  2  Shri Ganesh Das, son of Shri Chote Das of Gour Mondal Road, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan companymitted theft in respect of electric companyper wire  about 1500 ft. in length  at Hatgarui near Sen-Releigh Water Pump, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan. As a result of this theft, water supply as 9 92 well as electric supply in Sen-Releigh Housing Colony, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan was totally disrupted for about 8 hours to the sufferings of the people of the locality.

facts.text: On January 12, 1972 at about 04.00 hrs, petitioner along with associates Teka Bahadur son of Harak Bir Bahadur of Hutton Road and Ganesh Das son of Chote Das of Gour Mondal Road, both P.S. Asansol Dist. Burdwan committed theft of electric copper wire about 3000 ft from electric poles at C Block, Son Releigh Housing Colony, P.S. Asansol Dist. Burdwan; when challenged by inhabitants, hurled bombs towards them, disrupting electric supply for more than 12 hours.

anchor.surface_text: That on 12-1-72 at about 04.00 hrs. you along with your associates including  1  Teka Bahadur son of Shri Harak Bir Bahadur of Hutton Road, P.S. Asansol Dist. Burdwan  2  Ganesh Das, son of Shri Chote Das of Gour Mondal Road, P.S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan companymitted theft in respect of electric companyper wire  about 3000 ft. in length  from the electric poles at C Block, Son Releigh Housing Colony, P.S. Asansol Dist. Burdwan. When challenged by the inhabitants of the area. you and your associates hurled bombs to- wards them. By your act, electric supply was totally disrupted in C Block area, Sen Releigh Housing Estate and its adjoining areas for more than 12 hours causing much inconvenience to the people of the loca- lity,

facts.text: Fact of detention order reported to State Government on February 9, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The fact of making the order of detention was duly reported to the State Government on February 9, 1972, the date of the order.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on February 21, 1972 and submitted report to Central Government same day.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government approved that order on February 21, 1972 and the necessary report submitted to the Central Government the same day.

facts.text: Petitioner produced before and heard in person by Advisory Board on April 10, 1972; Board gave decision same day.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, as stated by him in the petition for habeas companypus, was produced before and heard in person, by the Advisory Board on April 10, 1972. The Board, according to the respondent, gave its decision the same day.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation received by State Government on March 16, 1972 and considered on March 22, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The representation made by the petitioner was received by the State Government on March 16, 1972 and companysidered by the said Government on March 22, 1972.

facts.text: State Government confirmed order of detention on May 5, 1972 and communicated to detenu same day.

anchor.surface_text: The, State Government companyfined the order of detention on May 5, 1972 and companymunicated its order to the detenu the same day.

facts.text: Two cases for theft of copper wires under s.379 IPC registered against petitioner at Asansol Police Station: Case number 16 dated January 6, 1972 and Case number 20 dated January 12, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: according to the return itself, two cases for theft of companyper wires under s. 379, I.P.C. were registered against the petitioner and others at the Asansol Police Station  Case number 16 dated 6th January, 1972 and case number 20 dated 12th January, 1972 ,

facts.text: Witnesses examined under s.161 Cr.P.C. reluctant to depose against petitioner and associates for fear of danger to lives; Investigating Officer submitted final report suspecting petitioner and associates.

anchor.surface_text: but as the witnesses examined under s. 161, Cr.P.C. were reluctant to depose against petitioner and his associates for fear of danger to their lives, the Investigating Officer submitted as true, his final report suspecting the petitioner and his associates.

facts.text: State Government order of approval dated February 21, 1972, signed by Deputy Secretary on that day, though counter-affidavit stated February 18, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: According to the companynter-affidavit the order of detention has been approved by the State Government under s. 3  3  of the Act on February 18, 1972. This is clearly incorrect. We find from the original order of approval from the record  which was produced by the companynsel for the State under our directions  that it was draft on February 19, 1972 but actually signed by the Deputy Secretary on behalf of the Government on February 21, 1972.

issues.text: Whether the order of detention is mala fide and liable to be quashed merely because criminal cases under s. 379 I.P.C. failed due to reluctance of witnesses examined under s. 161 Cr.P.C. to depose against the petitioner and his associates

anchor.surface_text: The only submission pressed by Shri Jagmohan, the learned counsel appearing as amicus curiae in support of the writ petition, in assailing the order of detention is that, according to the return itself, two cases for theft of copper wires under s. 379, I.P.C. were registered against the petitioner and others at the Asansol Police Station  Case number 16 dated 6th January, 1972 and case number 20 dated 12th January, 1972 , but as the witnesses examined under s. 161, Cr.P.C. were reluctant to depose against petitioner and his associates for fear of danger to their lives,

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are clear, relevant and germane to the object of preventive detention under s. 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 for preventing acts prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community
Whether preventive detention under the Act is barred or rendered mala fide if criminal prosecution fails or proceedings under Chapter VIII Cr.P.C. could be initiated instead

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. The Act was brought on the statute book in 1971 in order to provide for detention in certain cases for the purpose of maintenance of internal security and matters connected therewith. Its enactment was necessitated because in view of the prevailing situation in the country and the developments across the border it was considered necessary for urgent and effective preventive action in the interest of national security, to have powers of preventive detention to deal effectively with threats to the defence and the security of India because the existing laws available to deal with the situation were not found to be adequate.

arguments.claim: The order of detention is mala fide and liable to be quashed because the criminal cases under s.379 IPC failed due to witnesses' reluctance to depose.

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention was for this reason described by Shri Khanna as mala fide and, therefore, liable to be quashed. According to the learned counsel in such cases criminal trial is the only course open to the State and no order of detention is legally competent. The counsel added that if the criminal trial fails or the case is not launched because it is liable to fail, the State has to remain content with the result. It cannot deprive the suspected person of his liberty under the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: urity, to have powers of preventive detention to deal effectively with threats to the defence and the security of India because the existing laws avai

arguments.court_reasoning: Preventive detention under the Act is distinct from criminal prosecution for offences; failure of prosecution or witness reluctance does not render detention mala fide or incompetent.

arguments.claim: Criminal trial is the only course open to the State in such cases and no order of detention is legally competent.

anchor.surface_text: According to the learned counsel in such cases criminal trial is the only course open to the State and no order of detention is legally competent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: urity, to have powers of preventive detention to deal effectively with threats to the defence and the security of India because the existing laws avai

arguments.court_reasoning: The Act creates a separate jurisdiction for preventive detention based on subjective satisfaction, distinct from judicial trial for offences.

arguments.claim: If criminal trial fails or case not launched due to likelihood of failure, State cannot detain under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The counsel added that if the criminal trial fails or the case is not launched because it is liable to fail, the State has to remain content with the result. It cannot deprive the suspected person of his liberty under the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: urity, to have powers of preventive detention to deal effectively with threats to the defence and the security of India because the existing laws avai

arguments.court_reasoning: Unsuccessful prosecution does not bar preventive detention; Act applies precisely when ordinary laws are inadequate to prevent future prejudicial acts.

arguments.claim: The Act enables preventive detention for maintenance of internal security where existing laws are inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. The Act was brought on the statute book in 1971 in order to provide for detention in certain cases for the purpose of maintenance of internal security and matters connected therewith.

arguments.claim: Under s.3(1) and (2) of the Act, detention order valid on subjective satisfaction to prevent prejudicial acts to supplies essential to community.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 1  of the Act, the Central Government or the State Government may, if satisfied with respect to any person, that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to, inter alia, the security of the State or the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community, it is necessary to, do so, make an order directing that such person be detained.

arguments.claim: Detention order cannot be challenged merely because person liable to criminal trial or Chapter VIII CrPC proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order in such a case cannot be challenged on the ground that the person ordered to be detained was liable to be tried for the commission of the offence or offences founded on his conduct, on the basis of which, the detention order has been made or that proceedings under Chapter Vill, Cr.P.C. could be initiated against him.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India holds that dropping prosecution does not make detention mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: The matter is also not res integra. Indeed, while dealing with the Defence of India Rules which also empowered the Government of India to make orders of prevenitive detention this Court in Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India repelled a similar contention in the following words The next contention on behalf of the petitioners is that the order is mala fide.

arguments.claim: Precedents in Mohd. Salim Khan and Borjahan Gorey v. State of West Bengal support that preventive detention operates independently of criminal prosecution.
Grounds of detention are clear, relevant and germane as thefts disrupted essential supplies.
Cases of Arun Kumar v. State of West Bengal and Sasti Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal support validity of detention.
arguments.court_reasoning: Court notes the cases in support without disagreement.

arguments.claim: Personal liberty not absolute; subject to reasonable restrictions for society interests including essential services.

holdings.text: The detention order in such a case cannot be challenged on the ground that the person ordered to be detained was liable to be tried for the commission of the offence or offences founded on his conduct, on the basis of which, the detention order has been made or that proceedings under Chapter Vill, Cr.P.C. could be initiated against him.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order in such a case cannot be challenged on the ground that the person ordered to be detained was liable to be tried for the commission of the offence or offences founded on his conduct, on the basis of which, the detention order has been made or that proceedings under Chapter Vill, Cr.P.C. could be initiated against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention under the Act is a distinct jurisdiction based on subjective satisfaction to prevent future prejudicial acts, separate from punitive criminal trials or preventive proceedings under CrPC, and existing laws are inadequate for such purposes.

holdings.text: Even unsuccessful judicial trial or proceeding would, therefore, not operate as a bar to a detention order or render it mala fide.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dropping or failure of prosecution due to insufficient evidence does not imply mala fides, as preventive detention targets future conduct based on suspicion from past activities, supported by precedents like Sahib Singh Dugal.

holdings.text: The grounds on the basis of which the petitioner has been detained are clear, relevant and germane to the object and purpose for which preventive detention is authorised by the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: The specific acts of theft of electric copper wires disrupting water and electric supplies for hours are directly prejudicial to maintenance of essential supplies and services under s.3 MISA.

holdings.text: The detention order is not open to challenge in these proceedings on the grounds averred in the writ petition and urged by the learned counsel at the bar.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected based on validity of subjective satisfaction, relevance of grounds, and distinction from criminal process.

holdings.text: This petition fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This petition fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No merits in challenges to detention order; all procedural and substantive requirements satisfied.

holdings.text: The order of approval must, therefore, be considered to have been made only on the day when it was signed, i.e., February 21, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: According to the counter-affidavit the order of detention has been approved by the State Government under s. 3  3  of the Act on February 18, 1972. This is clearly incorrect. We find from the original order of approval from the record  which was produced by the counsel for the State under our directions  that it was draft on February 19, 1972 but actually signed by the Deputy Secretary on behalf of the Government on February 21, 1972.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original document shows signing date as effective date of approval under s.3(3), correcting affidavit misstatement; no prejudice to detention validity.

holdings.text: NO doubt, the right to Personal liberty of an individual is jealously protected by our Constitution but this liberty is not absolute and is not to be understood to amount to licence to indulge in activities which wrongfully and unjustly deprive the community of the society of essential services and supplies.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances individual liberty against societal interests in essential services.

precedents.citation: Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India 1966 1 S.C.R. 313

anchor.surface_text: Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India 1

precedents.case_name: Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: order of detention not mala fide merely because criminal proceedings dropped due to insufficient evidence to secure conviction
precedents.cited_holding: It may very well be that the executive authorities felt that it was not possible to obtain a conviction for a particular offence under the Official Secrets Act, at the same time they might reasonably come to the conclusion that the activities of the petitioners... were of such a nature as to justify the order of detention.

precedents.case_name: Borjahan Gorey v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: preventive detention distinct from criminal trial; can be invoked even if evidence insufficient for judicial proof or witnesses scared
precedents.cited_holding: The jurisdiction under the Act may be invoked, when the available evidence does not come up to the standard of judicial proof but is otherwise sufficient enough to give rise to suspicion... or even when the witnesses may be frightened or scared of coming to a court and deposing about past acts.
